subject: meta-google: gbmc-bridge: Add package
commitMessage:
meta-google: gbmc-bridge: Add package

This adds a machine local ethernet network which allows BMCs to
communicate with one another.

Change-Id: I5e0ace231af02d84f7678b8241b5ec71823e86af
Signed-off-by: William A. Kennington III <wak@google.com>

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 832f02b111487b37e71c0170795cb0db6ce1732a by William A. Kennington III

We have to explicitly hardcode the mac address?  Wouldn't we just become an  L2 router for all devices on a specific NIC?  Or is it more complicated than that?

It seems odd we would hardcode a mac address like this.

You don't have to, by default (empty) it will use a random one. If you have some other program configuring the MAC from a FRU, that will override this configuration. This is mostly used to have a fixed endpoint when we know only a single BMC of a specific type will ever exist in a machine. Currently that's useful as I haven't implemented tool side discovery yet, and the fixed address gives us a consistent point of contact.
Do you have to explicitly check for empty string here?
Yeah, otherwise it will produce an exception when used.
Nit, a left shift by 8 might be more clear as to what's going on.
Probably did this to avoid parenthesis.
nit: maybe add bmc into this to make the naming more obvious?

I wanted to keep this concise. I would have called it `gbmc-br` like it is on the host side, but I can't because phosphor-networkd doesn't like any separators in the name. I guess I could call it gbmcbr or something but I wasn't happy with that and left it like it is downstream.
Magic numbers (I'm sure covered in ipv6 somewhere) maybe needs a comment so unsuspecting people know what to google.
Done
Might want to mention in the commit message how the cost function was chosen.  That seems important.
Done
nit, should the above 3 config files be checked in separately and sed replaced into place like the ipmi service file?
Done
Might want to mention in the commit message why we need to explicitly drop NCSI traffic.
Done

I'm far from an expert here, so this is more of a question.  What's the advantage of separating these directives as separate chains and jumping to them instead of just inline them.  Does it change behavior, or is it just an organization thing?
This is separated so that rules can be added to the end of the chain dynamically. Otherwise, you would have to figure out where in the middle of gbmc_br_input to add those rules.
Also not an expert here, but this looks like a DNS forward for IPMI?
mDNS, for the local network to be able to detect the machine. I didn't really need a specific service, but all of our machines have IPMI so I did that. I could change it to anything.
If we replaced mgmt with gbmcbr, do we still need this?
We still have mgmt in use downstream, I'll remove it once I transition everything away.
